org.logicmill.util.concurrent

Class KeySet<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.logicmill.util.concurrent.KeySet<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    KeySource<T>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    RandomKeySet

    public abstract class KeySet<T>
extends java.lang.Object
implements KeySource<T>
    A container for managing a set of memory-resident byte-array keys. KeySet supports performance testing of hash functions; a large number of readily-available keys can be supplied to a hash function under test without the overhead of constructing keys, generating random numbers, or reading keys from a file. KeySets are also useful for managing collections of keys with known stress-inducing properties (with respect to hash functions), where the same collection of keys can be hashed by multiple functions for comparative purposes.

    A concrete sub-class must implement a constructor that initializes the keys array and sets keyCount, and implement getKeySizeHint.

    Author:
    David Curtis

        public T getKey()
        Returns the next available key in the set. If the set is exhausted, getKey will return null.
        Specified by:

      • getKey

        public T getKey(int i)

        Parameters:
        i - index of the key to be returned
        Returns:
        the specified key
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if i < 0 or i >= number of keys in this set

      • shuffle

        public void shuffle(long seed)
        Re-orders the sequence to a pseudo-random permutation. Has utility for performance testing in some cases -- if keys are allocated from the heap as they are added, performance measurements may be skewed by caching.
        Parameters:
        seed - for the random number generator; different values result in different permutations
